inside the plastic tube that contains a mixture of hydrogen peroxide (the tingly feeling in your mouth) in phthalic ester. Outside of the glass vial is another chemical called phenyl oxalate ester. Dibutyl phthalate and phthalic ester is used to help make plastics soft and flexible, so that's what melted your gloves.
These chemicals can sting and burn eyes, irritate and sting skin and can burn the mouth and throat if ingested. If the chemicals are ingested or spilled in the eyes or on the skin, it is recommended the area is rinsed with water and the local poison control center contacted. Also the glass can shatter and grains the size of salt can be produced, this is a known killer and was used in place of salt or sugar in China hundreds of years ago in place of poison.

I would work with phenyl oxalate ester and hydrogen peroxide alone to produce luminescence instead. Or better yet Zinc sulfide as it's much safer and non-toxic. I have also seen people using a black light with tonic water (quinine water), or strontium based glow powder.

The liquid that is in the plastic casing is 30% hydrogen peroxide, so the activator is the same in every glow stick. The liquid in the glass capsule is a a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon, there are different types for each color. The tingling sensation on your tongue comes from the hydrogen peroxide, it's non-toxic but corrosive, so be careful with that.

Though generic and specific, a liquid containing quinine under a UV light could have been used to represent the drinking part (Tonic water contains a small amount of quinine). The quinine contains phosphors, which absorb energy from the UV light, causing electrons to gain more energy, and those which have a smaller ionization energy (valence electrons), start jumping over orbitals, and creating photons, seen as the blueish light. Thus it fluoresces.
